p.s: Starr's state of mind throughout this excerpt is visualized through narrative techniques and perspectives used by the author in order to successfully convey the significance of this part for the novel.

Just like throughout the whole novel, the events are told by the first person protagonist narrator, which means that we see the story through Starr's eyes and are deeply emotionally involved with her.
This is very effective, since the reader experiences the story like she does and can therforetherefore relate to her easily.
This is vivid at the beginning of the excerpt as we follow Starr's interior monologue, which is suddenly cut off by direct speech (ll. 5-8).
The reader is experiencing her thoughts as if they are his own until a chant is heard and the reader gets thrown off the interior monologue just like Starr.

Inbetween Starr is muttering the phrase A hairbrush is not a gun she has flashback of the incident, which makes Khalil's death for her and the reader present again, which leads to her shouting the phrase (ll. 18-23).
This way the reader understands the sudden change in volume in her voice and feels for her.
Overall the different techniques used make an illusion of a first-hand experience of the reader, which is why the story is so effective and impactful.
